Award.AwardTitle: Hispanics in the Pipeline: Foundations of Persistence from Middle School to STEM Careers

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The study, conducted by researchers at the University of California-Irvine, and the University of Michigan, will examine the underrepresentation of Hispanics in STEM fields. Hispanic youth, the largest minority and fastest growing demographic group, are the most likely to drop out of the STEM pipeline before college and are the least likely to complete college STEM training. Understanding the psychosocial non-cognitive influences on Hispanic youth's educational and occupational decisions is critical for designing effective strategies to confront this issue. The researchers will document the association of these non-cognitive constructs with Hispanic youth's STEM-related educational and occupational choices and persistence. The project will be funded by the EHR Core Research (ECR) program, which supports fundamental research on STEM learning and education.

The study builds on an existing longitudinal study of 14,000 mostly Hispanic and low-income middle and high school students to create a 15-year database. It also follows up on 1500 Hispanic youths with a more targeted survey. This study will contribute to the further refinement of two major social-cognitive/motivational theories of educational success and educational and occupational choices: Achievement Goal Theory (AGT) and Expectancy-Value Theory (EVT), documenting their association with Hispanic youth's STEM-related educational and occupational persistence. The longitudinal dataset will include measures of such essential constructs as: (a) self-efficacy, mindsets, subjective task values, and affective experiences, (b) educational and career aspirations and attainment, (c) high school course choices, and (d) academic achievement. The researchers will examine the links between these constructs assessed in secondary school and post high school educational and occupational choices and persistence. Finally, the researchers will assess the links between students' experiences in math classrooms, immediate over-the-year changes (motivational beliefs, college and career aspirations) and long-term outcomes (college and occupational choices).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project builds on an existing longitudinal study of middle and high school students? math-related beliefs, STEM aspirations, and achievement. Our study made important contributions towards our understanding of motivated behavior for understudied groups of students‒mostly English Learner and low-income Hispanic youth. We examined how classroom experiences and motivational beliefs contribute to students? STEM-related educational and occupational choices and persistence. Findings from this study help us better understand the a) engagement, and achievement and b) the educational and occupational aspirations of underrepresented students. In addition, the project created an extended longitudinal database by following up with some of the original participants of the study (now in their mid-to late 20s) to learn about how their motivational beliefs and aspirations in adolescence related to their educational and occupational choices 15 years later.

a)     Engagement and achievement over time

We find that Hispanic youths? confidence in their ability to succeed (?Can I do this??) and the perceived subjective value of their efforts (?Is this worth it??) are key for their short- and long-term math achievement and course enrollments. These beliefs about math are linked with the courses that they take and how well they do in them across their high school career and also their likelihood of graduating from high school and being eligible for college enrollment. Their confidence in their math abilities was consistently linked to their math achievement and their interest in math made it more likely for them to continue taking math courses. These beliefs, however, decline throughout adolescence.

Our study also highlighted important gender differences: Hispanic males had greater confidence and valued math more than Hispanic females, while Hispanic females performed better overall and persisted over time?taking a greater number of courses and advanced courses relative to their male peers. More Hispanic females than males satisfied their high school graduation requirements and university admissions requirements. Finding importance in math especially mattered for Hispanic females, their math course-taking, and fulfilling their high school graduation requirements. Finding usefulness in math mattered to Hispanic males for fulfilling college eligibility requirements.

Emerging work from our most recent wave of data collection shows that if Hispanic females received some type of support in their high school studies, or educational and career planning from their family, they were more likely to receive a higher educational degree in young adulthood.

Influence of classroom experiences on achievement and engagement

We also investigated the influence of classroom experiences on Hispanic students? engagement. Findings show that the decline in math motivational beliefs across adolescence was buffered when students felt that their math teacher was caring towards them. We find that the students benefited not only from the emotional support of their teachers but also from their cognitive support and from the teacher's support for collaborative work between students. These findings highlight important ways in which teachers can help Hispanic students to stay engaged in their classrooms.

b)     Educational and occupational aspirations

Our study further supports findings that Hispanic youth generally endorse high educational aspirations. Nearly three-quarters of our surveyed students in grade 9 wanted to at least go to a 4-year college. Educational aspirations decreased as students got older and more mature, though. One buffer against this decrease in aspirations was students? interest. The more interested students were in math in grade 9, the more likely they were to maintain their educational aspirations over time. We also found that Hispanic females aspired to higher levels of education and to occupations that required higher education than Hispanic males did.

We find that the occupational aspirations of our participating Hispanic youth fall along gender stereotypic lines. For instance, males aspired to careers as athletes, law enforcement professionals, construction professionals and females aspired to careers as healthcare professionals, lawyers and teachers. However, the aspirations of youth changed over time. In grade 7, most of our Hispanic boys aspired to professions within Arts, Entertainment, and Sports. By grade 12, their career aspirations had significantly diversified as more males aspired to STEM, Maintenance, and Business and Education professions. Having a greater interest in math and seeing it as useful for their life was also linked to students desiring a future occupation that required more math knowledge, particularly for Hispanic males.

One central finding of our study is that the pattern of students? STEM aspirations does not match the lack of Hispanic representation in STEM jobs described in existing research. Taking into account healthcare occupations along with more traditional STEM jobs, a significant proportion of Hispanic youth, male and female, actually aspired to these occupations (between 30% and 40%). This highlights not only the need for the inclusion of a broad set of STEM occupations but also points to the need for more research on why Hispanic youths? STEM aspirations do not come to fruition.
